security_audit.summary: This is a pure scientific visualization skill. It contains Python helper scripts that configure matplotlib settings and export figures to local files. No network calls, no credential access, no code execution hooks. The filesystem access is limited to saving user-specified figure outputs.

low_findings.title: Local file write operations in export script
low_findings.description: The figure_export.py script writes figures to local files using matplotlib's savefig functionality. The code at lines 61-95 saves figures to user-specified paths via fig.savefig(). This is expected behavior for a visualization export tool and poses minimal risk as output paths are user-controlled.

content.value_statement: Scientific figures often fail journal requirements for size, format, and accessibility. This skill guides you to build publication-ready plots with correct styling and export settings for matplotlib, seaborn, and plotly.
actual_capabilities: Apply publication matplotlib style presets and colorblind-safe palettes
Configure figures for Nature, Science, Cell, PLOS, ACS, and IEEE sizing
Export figures in PDF, EPS, TIFF, and PNG with DPI control
Check figure size compliance against journal specifications
Create multi-panel layouts with panel labeling and consistent spacing
Use Okabe-Ito and other colorblind-friendly color palettes
limitations: Does not generate or analyze data for you
Requires matplotlib, seaborn, and plotly to be installed
Plotly static image export needs kaleido package installed
Journal requirements can change and must be verified manually

use_cases.title: Prepare figure for submission
use_cases.description: Format a multi-panel figure to meet Nature or Science size, font, and export requirements.

use_cases.title: Standardize lab figure styles
use_cases.description: Apply a shared publication style and colorblind-safe palette across figures for consistent manuscripts.

use_cases.title: Create accessible statistical plots
use_cases.description: Build colorblind-friendly plots with error bars and clear labeling for scientific reports.

prompt_templates.title: Create clean plot
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a publication-ready line plot template in matplotlib with axis labels, error bars, and colorblind-safe colors.

prompt_templates.title: Check journal sizing
prompt_templates.prompt: Check if my 3.5 by 2.5 inch figure fits Nature single-column requirements and suggest adjustments.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-panel layout
prompt_templates.prompt: Design a 2x2 multi-panel layout with panel labels and consistent spacing for journal submission.

prompt_templates.title: Journal-specific export
prompt_templates.prompt: Export a figure for Cell as line art with correct DPI and file formats, then explain the chosen settings.

output_examples.input: Format a Nature single-column figure and list the export settings.
output: Set figure width to 89 mm with 4:3 aspect ratio.
Applied Nature style with smaller font sizes and thin lines.
Exported as PDF at 600 DPI for combination figures.
Suggested EPS at 1000 DPI for pure line art.

best_practices: Use vector formats (PDF, EPS) for plots and TIFF or PNG for images
Apply colorblind-safe palettes and test grayscale output
Verify figure size against target journal specifications before export
anti_patterns: Using JPEG format for plots or line art
Relying only on color without markers or line styles
Exporting raster images below journal DPI requirements

faq.question: Is this compatible with my setup?
faq.answer: It works with matplotlib, seaborn, and plotly in Python. Install these libraries first before using the skill.

faq.question: What are the main limits?
faq.answer: This skill does not create data or perform statistical analysis. It focuses on styling, layout, and export settings.

faq.question: Can I integrate it with my workflow?
faq.answer: Yes. Import the helper scripts or style files into your Jupyter notebooks or data analysis pipelines.

faq.question: Does it access my data or credentials?
faq.answer: No. The skill uses local plotting settings and file exports only. No network calls are made.

faq.question: What if a style does not apply correctly?
faq.answer: Check the journal guidelines for exact requirements. Adjust font sizes, DPI, and figure width using the provided helpers.

faq.question: How does it compare to a general plotting guide?
faq.answer: This skill includes journal sizing specifications, export presets, and colorblind palettes focused specifically on publication standards.
